title: General Course Policies
text:
Academic integrity

Students must maintain academic integrity (no cheating, plagiarism, unauthorized materials, falsification, etc.).
Violations follow SCTCC Academic Integrity Policy/Procedure and may be recorded; disciplinary action may apply.
Academic integrity violations result in a grade reduction.



Professional conduct and behavior (online + communication)

Online discussions must be civil, respectful, and relevant.
Disruptive behavior on any course communication platform is not tolerated; may result in grade penalties and/or removal per the Code of Student Conduct.
Respect for differing viewpoints is required; maintain professional language and conduct.
If disruptive behavior causes a student to miss an assignment, they receive no credit for that assignment.
If sanctioned for disruptive behavior, students waive the right to a warning on a second occurrence.
Substance policy for online sessions: inebriation/being under the influence, displaying alcohol, or drug paraphernalia results in removal from the session and/or course; no smoking during online school activites.



Student privacy / third-party communication

Course progress is discussed only with the student, not parents/guardians/third parties, unless an Information Release is on file.
If a third party contacts the instructor, the instructor will defer communication to the student.
Students may not invite third parties to attend any online activity (office hours, group meetings).
Requests to release progress information to a third party should go through the Dean’s office.



Attendance / participation (online definition + consequences)

Attendance is expected and monitored; students are responsible for tracking absences.
Attendance is determined by D2L logins and weekly assignment submissions.
Not logging in and/or not submitting work for a week counts as an absence (including weeks without due assignments unless it’s a scheduled holiday/break).
Students must log in and complete an activity by 11:30 PM on the first Wednesday of week 1 or they may be dropped.
Missing two consecutive weeks → dropped.
Missing two total weeks → one-letter-grade reduction (10% of total points).
Missing three total weeks → an additional one-letter-grade reduction.
Additional absences beyond three → additional letter-grade reduction per occurrence.
Attendance is handled per class (one class doesn’t cover another).



Technology and platform expectations

Students are responsible for having required computer/technology for the course.
Students are responsible for learning and using D2L (primary channel for schedules, grades, and announcements).



Email communication

Email is the primary method to contact the instructor; students must use their college email account.
Emails must include a subject line with course name and section/class time.
Students are expected to check email daily and read instructor messages/attachments.
On nights homework is due, only administrative email items will be answered; technical homework questions will not be addressed.
Response time: by end of next business day; Friday emails answered Monday.

title: Week 1 — VSCode Setup and First Notebook (Windows)
text:
What you’re doing
You are going to open a Jupyter notebook in VS Code and run it successfully using the course Python environment.


1) Open the course folder in VS Code

Open VS Code
Go to File → Open Folder…
Open your course work folder (example: C:\cmsc-1217\)



2) Install the extensions (if you don’t already have them)
In VS Code, install:

Python (Microsoft)
Jupyter (Microsoft)



3) Create the course Python environment and select it in VS Code (one-time)

3A) Create the course environment folder

Create a folder on your C: drive named:

C:\cmsc-1217-env\




3B) Create the virtual environment (.venv)

Open Command Prompt (Windows search → type “Command Prompt”)
Run:

cd C:\cmsc-1217-env
python -m venv .venv


3C) Activate the environment
In the same Command Prompt window, run:
C:\cmsc-1217-env\.venv\Scripts\activate.bat
You should see (.venv) appear at the start of the line.


3D) Install the notebook packages (first-time setup)
Still in the activated environment, run:
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
python -m pip install numpy pandas matplotlib jupyter


3E) Select the environment in VS Code (Interpreter)

In VS Code, press Ctrl + Shift + P
Type Python: Select Interpreter
Choose the interpreter that looks like:


C:\cmsc-1217-env\.venv\Scripts\python.exe

If you don’t see it:

choose Enter interpreter path…
paste: C:\cmsc-1217-env\.venv\Scripts\python.exe

This is the environment we will use all semester.



4) Open the notebook

In the Explorer panel, click the notebook file (.ipynb) your instructor provided.



5) Select the notebook kernel (first time only)
The first time you run a notebook, VS Code may ask you to pick a kernel.
Choose the kernel that matches the course environment path:

C:\cmsc-1217-env\.venv\Scripts\python.exe

This can feel repetitive the first time. That’s normal. Once selected, it usually stays set for that folder.


6) Select the kernel, then run a quick test

In the top-right of the notebook, click Select Kernel.
Choose the kernel that points to the course environment:
C:\cmsc-1217-env\.venv\Scripts\python.exe
(It may also show up as “Python 3.x (.venv)”—the key is that it points to cmsc-1217-env\.venv.)
Click + Code.
In the code block that appears, paste:

print("Notebook is running")

Run it by clicking the Run (▶) icon on the code block, or press Shift + Enter.
You should see Notebook is running appear underneath.



7) Quick confirmation (your instructor may ask for this)
Run this in a cell:
import sys
sys.executable
It should show something like:
C:\cmsc-1217-env\.venv\Scripts\python.exe


If something goes wrong

If you see ModuleNotFoundError (missing package), you are almost always using the wrong interpreter/kernel.

Re-do Step 3 and Step 5 and pick the one that points to cmsc-1217-env\.venv.

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Instructor(s): Joseph Silman Office: Online
E-mail: jsilman@sctcc.edu (PRIMARY COMMUNICATION METHOD) Phone: (320)308-6595
Office Hours: See Attached Course Schedule in D2L.
Credits: 3 (Lecture 2; Lab 1)

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Course Description
This course introduces data analytics using Python to extract and communicate insights from datasets.
Students acquire foundational skills in data manipulation, including transformation and cleansing, alongside techniques for visualizing data distributions and managing file-based data input/output, preparing them for machine learning applications in subsequent semesters. The course focuses on technical concepts such as trend identification through graphical analysis, data structuring for computational efficiency, and processing real-world datasets for artificial intelligence applications. Through programming exercises and a capstone project analyzing a representative dataset, students develop practical Python programming competencies essential for advanced coursework in machine learning.

Course Philosophy
This course follows a tools-first approach to “data analytics.” Our focus is on the Python programming skills and the data library ecosystem (especially pandas and related tools) used to manipulate, process, clean, and summarize real datasets. We will cover analytical concepts only as needed to motivate a tool or technique, but this course is not focused on statistical methodology (hypothesis testing, inference, or model theory), which is addressed in other courses.
This online class requires extensive use of your webcam

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Course Outcomes

Upon completion of this course the student will:

Identify fundamental concepts of data analytics and their role in preparing data for machine learning applications.
Explain how Python programming streamlines data analysis processes for real-world datasets.
Manipulate datasets in Python, including filtering, sorting, and handling missing values.
Compare Python data visualization techniques to represent data trends effectively.
Assess the quality of a dataset’s preparation in Python, identifying areas for improvement in data cleaning and transformation for machine learning readiness.
Design a data analytics project in Python to extract insights from a real-world dataset.

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Course Content

Introduction to Data Analytics with Python
Python Libraries for Data Manipulation (Pandas)
Data Cleaning and Preparation in Python
Data Visualization with Matplotlib and Seaborn
Working with File-Based Data (CSV, JSON)
Capstone Data Analytics Project

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Required Materials
Python for Data Analyis, 3rd Edition : Wes McKinney
Computer running current OS that supports Microsoft Office
Webcam Required
*** STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO HAVE THEIR MATERIALS AT THE START OF THE COURSE***

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Grading/Evaluation
Tests, textbook problems, individual projects, video assignments, and performance will be graded. Grades will be updated in D2L and you are responsible for verifying that your grades are correct. Academic Progress reports will only be sent out to students earning a grade of a “D” or lower. Course Grades will be per the following criteria:
A = 100 – 90%
B = 89 – 80%
C = 79 – 70%
D = 69 – 60 %
F = Below 60 %
Grades are weighted as follows:

Labs - 45%
Video Activities – 40%
D2L Quizzes/Tests – 15%

Some assignments will be based off a pass/fail criterion. Grading Rubrics will be assigned to most course activities. Some assignments are automatically graded. Activities may be assigned but not be graded, these are for self-review to prepare you for graded activities. ‘Proof’ files will be provided to you on occasion to help you identify any issues with your assignment. It is expected that you review these when you receive your rubric feedback. Extra credit assignments or additional assignments are not offered in this course.

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Course Policies/Practices

Academic Integrity
Academic integrity is highly valued at St. Cloud Technical & Community College and throughout higher education. Maintaining academic integrity is the responsibility of every member of the college community: faculty, staff, administrators and students. Academic integrity requires students to refrain from engaging in or tolerating acts including, but not limited to, submitting false academic records, cheating, plagiarizing, altering, forging, or misusing a college academic record; acquiring or using test materials without faculty permission; acting alone or in cooperation with another to falsify records or to obtain dishonest grades, honors, or awards.
Any violation of the St. Cloud Technical & Community College’s Academic Integrity Policy S3.28 is considered a disciplinary offense and will be subject to the policies of this instructor, entrance into the Academic Integrity Database, and possible disciplinary action as outlined in the Academic Integrity Procedure S3.28.1. Students accused of academic dishonesty may appeal the decision. Students may review the Academic Integrity process and access the Academic Integrity Appeal Form at https://www.sctcc.edu/academic-integrity.
Class policy for Academic Integrity Violations will result in a reduction of your grade.
http://sctcc.edu/sites/default/files/policies/S3.24%20Complaint%20Grievance.pdf


Classroom Behavior
Attendance is a necessary part of this course. Refer to the attendance policy outlined later in the syllabus
Online discussions should be civilized and respectful to everyone and relevant to the topic we are discussing.
Disruptive behavior on any communication platform will not be tolerated.
You are expected to do your own work unless otherwise directed. Cheating, plagiarism, and any other form of academic dishonesty will not be tolerated. Please refer to the Code of Student Conduct and Academic Integrity policy for details.
Any indication of inebriation or being under the influence, and/or displaying of alcohol or use of paraphernalia that could be associated with drug usage during assignments/course activities will result in removal from the session and/or course. No smoking during any online sessions. My policy is to remove you from the course and leave it to you to file a grievance to return.
Meaningful and constructive dialogue is encouraged, but this also requires a degree of mutual respect, willingness to listen, and tolerance of opposing points of view. Respect for individual differences and alternative viewpoints will always be expected in this course. One’s words and use of language should be temperate and within acceptable bounds of civility and decency.
Disruptive behaviors, including excessive talking about off topic items, arriving late to the start of meetings or returning late from breaks, sleeping, reading, or watching media, or game playing is not permitted and will result in a grade penalty.
Extreme disruptive behavior, fighting (verbally), using repetitive profanity, personal or physical threats or insults, and angry outbursts, will result in your removal from the course in accordance with policies and procedures outlined in the SCTCC’s Code of Student Conduct.
If a student’s disruptive behavior causes them to miss an assignment, they will not receive credit for that assignment. If a student has been sanctioned due to disruptive behavior, they waive the right to a warning on a second occurrence.


Data Privacy and Student Course Progress
Students are encouraged to take ownership over their academic progress and communicate with faculty directly for any questions or concerns regarding their coursework. I am reachable at my listed contact information and office hours on this syllabus and happy to discuss your progress with you.
Per the College’s Student Data Practices policy, I am unable to share information about a student’s course progress to anyone other than the student, including third parties such as parents/guardians, unless a current Information Release is on file with the Records and Registration Office. Faculty are often unable to confirm if an Information Release is on file, so it is always preferred that the student speak with the faculty one-on-one.
Because of the items outlined above, should a third party contact me directly with a question or concern about your progress, I will defer my response to you and not the third party. Students shall also not invite third parties to attend class meetings (online), as this causes a disruption to the learning environment.
If a student would like their course progress information released to a third party, they may do so by contacting the Dean’s office to make a request for specific information to be shared with the third party.


Computer Requirements
A Computer meeting the program requirements and able to run multiple instances of Windows or Linux OS concurrently (using virtualization) is required for this class.
Computer requirements are outlined here:
https://www.sctcc.edu/degrees-programs/computer-programming


D2L
A fundamental understanding of D2L is required for this course as it is the primary method to communicate course schedules, grade information, and class news. It is the student’s responsibility to learn to navigate and find information on D2L. SCTCC does offer information sessions on this tool.


Attendance/Participation:
Attendance is expected and monitored. You are responsible for monitoring your attendance and your absence count.
Attendance will be determined by up to two contributing factors, logging into your D2L Brightspace course, and submission of weekly assignments. Failure to log into class and/or submit assignments for a week will result in an absence. Failure to log into class during a week where an assignment is not due and is not a scheduled holiday/spring break week will result in an absence. I will check logins and assignment submission for the previous week every Monday.
You must log into your online class and complete an activity by 11:30 PM on the first Wednesday of the first week of class. Failure to log in will result in being dropped from the course.
Missing two consecutive weeks of class will result in being dropped from the course.
Missing two total weeks of class (non-consecutive and any combination of unexcused/excused) will result in a reduction of one letter grade (10% of total points). Missing three total weeks of class will result in an additional reduction of a letter grade. Any absence over three will result in a further reduction of a letter grade for each occurrence. Classes I teach are considered independent of each other with respect to attendance. You may meet attendance requirements in one of my classes but fail attendance requirements in another class.


Testing:
D2L tests are electronic quizzes. These may be scheduled ahead of time or given without warning. If a D2L test is password protected, sharing passwords with another student will constitute an integrity violation.
Tests are not restricted to a specific day for this course but must be completed by the assignment due date as scheduled. You may have multiple attempts at an Online D2L quiz. Time for each question is normally 45 seconds per question. If multiple attempts are allowed, you must score greater than 60% on your first attempt to be allowed a second attempt and you must score greater than an 80% on your second attempt to be allowed a third attempt (if there is a third attempt). If you exceed the time limit on the quiz, the grading engine will mark the test as a 0 and will not allow any further work on your quiz. Always be aware of the time remaining on your quiz. You may not leave a quiz once you start it.
Note on auto generated D2L Tests: You may not be able to backtrack through the questions on a D2L quiz. The Next Page and Submit Button are close to each other on the test page. It is possible to Submit a quiz inadvertently if you are not paying attention so ensure that you are reading the popup messages.
Tests and quizzes cannot be made up.


Schedule
Subject to change based on instructor and class needs.


Assignments/Projects
All assignments must be turned in by the due date. Due dates will be announced during class and posted on D2L . Late assignments will not be accepted. A late assignment is any assignment that is not in the dropbox by the due/end date. Sometimes assignments will consist of two parts, a video submission, and a file submission. Missing either portion of the assignment will make the assignment ineligible for grading. Video assignments that cannot be accessed by the instructor at the time of grading will also not be accepted. All projects and assignments should be archived and kept. Any group work assigned is also ineligible for makeup so make sure that you are a responsible, considerate groupmate.
Types of assignments you may encounter in this course:
Weekly practice assignments – are based on the week’s topics. You will normally receive 5 – 7 days to complete these types of assignment.
Projects – are longer assignments that are bigger in scope than a practice assignment and usually have a timeline with concrete checkpoints. These assignments may be done in a group setting or individually depending on the project.
Video Assignments – are assignments in which you will use your webcam and record your desktop to complete a specific activity. Some video assignments are group-based activities. Ensure that you review the assignment and the assignment rubric for specific instructions.


Dress
Students are expected to dress in a manner that is considerate of their classmates and the instructor for any online video assignments.

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Standards for Materials Submitted
Specific standards for submitting assignments will be outlined by the instructor in the assignment instructions. Any assignment that does not follow these standards will not be accepted or subject to a significant grade penalty, this includes not submitting files in the correct file format and/or misnaming the file. If you have a question on a file submission, please ensure that you contact the instructor before the due date.

Student Email
Students will be expected to use email as the primary method of communication with the instructor. Students must use their college email account for all email communication with the instructor. Assignments will not be accepted via email. All students must abide by the following requirements:

If the subject line is missing, your email will not be accepted. The subject line MUST have your course name and course section/class time.
Students will check their email at least once per day.
Students will read all emails and attachments sent by the instructor.
Any attachments submitted via email must pertain to the course.

Email communication is encouraged, however only administrative items will be answered on the night homework is due. An example of an administrative item is informing me of the birth of a child. Technical questions regarding homework will not be addressed. The purpose behind this policy is to limit procrastination.
Expect email to be answered by the end of the next business day. Email sent on Friday will be answered the following Monday.

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Student Responsibilities/Contributions

Attendance and participation is crucial to succeed in this class.
Every student will be required to produce projects based on professional standard for the industry.
Every student is expected to turn in all work as assigned.
Every student is expected to work cooperatively with classmates and the instructor.

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Statement of Accomodations
St. Cloud Technical & Community College is committed to supporting students with disabilities in obtaining, understanding, and advocating for equitable and inclusive access in all aspects of their education and campus life. It is the role of Accessibility Services to provide and/or arrange reasonable accommodations to qualified students who have a disability (or have acquired a disability) during any point of their tenure at SCTCC. Accommodations are established through collaboration between students, Accessibility Services, faculty, and staff to empower students to pursue their academic goals free from barriers while upholding the integrity of the academic experience.
Disabilities take on several forms including but not limited to mental health, cognitive, learning, behavioral, chronic health/systemic, and physical.
If you have a disability (or think you may have a disability) contact Accessibility Services at 320-308-5064 or acc@sctcc.edu to establish an accommodation plan.
It is the responsibility of the student requesting accommodations to provide their instructor with their accommodation plan via email. It is encouraged that students with approved accommodations connect with their instructor as soon as they are able in order to proactively discuss how reasonable accommodation will be implemented in class and/or to address any concerns regarding emergency procedures. Students may submit their plan to faculty at any time during the semester, but accommodations cannot be retroactively applied.
More information and guidelines are available at www.sctcc.edu/accessibility.
This syllabus is available in alternate formats upon request by contacting Accessibility Services at 320-308-5757, 1-800-222-1009, or acc@sctcc.edu. TTY users may call MN Relay Service at 711 to contact the college. Discrimination against individuals on the grounds of disability is prohibited.

title: CMSC 1217 – Introduction to Data Analytics
text:
Statement of Diversity
The entire class will benefit from the wealth of diversity brought by each individual, so students are asked to extend every courtesy and respect that they, in turn, would expect from the class.
This college is committed to creating a positive, supportive environment that welcomes diversity of opinions and ideas for students. There will be no tolerance of race discrimination/harassment, sexual discrimination/harassment, or discrimination/harassment based on age, disability, color, creed, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, marital status, status with regard to public assistance, or membership in a local commission.

title: Week 2
text: This page will be published before Week 2 begins.

title: About
text: About this site

title: Week 1 Assignments
text: Submission location: All items are submitted in D2L (Week 1 dropboxes). Reading: Chapter 1 and Chapter 2 (complete).

title: Week 1 Assignments
text:
Part 1: Reading
Read all of Chapter 1 and all of Chapter 2.
Pay special attention to:

Chapter 1.3 Essential Python Libraries
Chapter 1.4 Installation and Setup
Chapter 1.6 Navigating This Book (import conventions, how to read examples)
Chapter 2.1–2.2 Interpreter + IPython/Jupyter workflow (tab completion, ? help)

title: Week 1 Assignments
text:
Part 2: Setup
Submit the following screenshots (each as a separate file):

Git installed Screenshot name: lastname_git-version.png Show the output of:


git --version


Course folders created Screenshot name: lastname_course-folders.png Show File Explorer displaying:


C:\cmsc-1217\course-work\
C:\cmsc-1217\book\
C:\cmsc-1217\data\


Book files cloned Screenshot name: lastname_book-clone.png Show either:


the successful git clone output, or
File Explorer showing: C:\cmsc-1217\book\pydata-book\


Conda environment exists Screenshot name: lastname_conda-env-list.png Show the output of:


conda info --envs


Core packages installed Screenshot name: lastname_pandas-version.png Show the output of:


python -c "import pandas as pd; print(pd.__version__)"

(We will keep a consistent pandas version for compatibility with course/book notebooks.)

title: Week 1 Assignments
text:
Part 3: JupyterLab practice

A) Launch JupyterLab in the correct folder
From Anaconda Prompt:

conda activate pydata-book
cd C:\cmsc-1217\course-work
jupyter lab



B) Create a Week01 folder in cmsc-1217 and then create and run a notebook
Create: week01-notebook-practice.ipynb in course-work\week01.
Run these cells:
import sys
sys.executable
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib
message = "Notebooks run Python too"
message
x = 10
x + 5
Then use JupyterLab to:

Restart the kernel
Run all cells

Finally, do:

Tab completion: type np.random. and use completion
Help/introspection:

np.random.standard_normal?
These behaviors are part of the Chapter 2 IPython/Jupyter workflow.


Required screenshots

JupyterLab opened in course-work Screenshot name: lastname_jupyterlab-course-work.png Show the JupyterLab file browser open in C:\cmsc-1217\course-work\week01.
sys.executable output Screenshot name: lastname_sys-executable.png
Introspection output (?) Screenshot name: lastname_ipython-help.png

title: Week 1 Assignments
text:
Part 4: IPython in a terminal
Open a new Anaconda Prompt tab/window:

conda activate pydata-book
ipython

Run at least one small example that produces an In [ ] and an Out [ ] (for example, assign a variable and then evaluate it).

IPython running Screenshot name: lastname_ipython-prompt.png Show the IPython prompt and at least one In [ ] / Out [ ] interaction.

title: Week 1 Assignments
text:
Part 5: D2L quiz
Complete the D2L Chapter 1 and Chapter 2 quiz.

title: Week 1 Assignments
text:
Part 6: Video reflection

Video Submission Instructions
Record a short video of yourself explaining your understanding of the Week 1 workflow. Focus on explaining concepts clearly and using correct terminology rather than reading text from the screen.
In your video, address:

What feels different from running .py scripts in an editor
What the kernel is (in your own words)
Why “restart the kernel” and “run all” are useful habits

Requirements

Clear video and audio quality
Introduce yourself at the beginning (name)
Name your video file: lastname_Week01Reflection
Upload your video to Kaltura
Do not embed the video in the Dropbox submission
Paste the share link into the D2L assignment text submission box
Make sure the link text includes lastname_Week01Reflectionin the link name. This will appear if you copy the link.

title: CMSC 1217 Course Schedule
text:
Weekly module opens: Monday 8:00 AM
Assignments due: Sunday 11:30 PM
Work cadence:

Mon–Thu: work through reading + practice notebook

title: CMSC 1217 Course Schedule
text:
Assessment intent

Practice Notebooks (completion): guided work with built-in self-check cells
Skill Checks (autograded notebooks): short, testable tasks (functions / named outputs)
Reflections (graded): brief, rubric-based video explanations of choices, debugging, and interpretation
Final Project (graded): notebook report + deliverables (Video Based)

title: CMSC 1217 Course Schedule
text:
Final project (Apr 27–May 11)
Deliverable (May 11, 2026): a single notebook-based report that demonstrates an end-to-end workflow.
Minimum components:

Load one real dataset (CSV/JSON/Excel)
Cleaning + preparation steps (with brief justification)
Wrangling/aggregation (at least one merge or groupby style task)
2–4 clear visualizations with labels
Short written narrative: what you did, what you found, limitations/next steps
Export at least one output artifact (cleaned CSV and/or saved figures)

title: Week 1 — Miniconda Setup and First Notebook (Windows)
text:
What you know from Structured: you installed Python from python.org, and VS Code used that Python.
What’s different here: instead of installing Python directly, we install Miniconda, which is an environment manager. Think of Miniconda as a tool that can install Python + data libraries into a self-contained folder so this course has a consistent setup.

Download and install Miniconda (64-bit).
During install, do not add Miniconda to PATH.

Why not add to PATH: you might already have a python.org install. We don’t want Miniconda to “take over” the python command everywhere on your machine. Instead, we’ll use the Miniconda/Anaconda Prompt when we want the course setup.

title: Week 1 — Miniconda Setup and First Notebook (Windows)
text:
Optional: IPython
Connection to what you know: this is like running Python in a terminal, but more helpful for exploration (history, tab completion, quick testing).

Open an Anaconda tab (not PowerShell)
If you’re using Windows Terminal:

Click the small dropdown arrow next to the plus (˅) (Do not just click the + — that usually opens PowerShell.)
Click Anaconda Prompt (miniconda3) (or “Anaconda PowerShell Prompt (miniconda3)” — either works, but the Prompt is simplest)

You should see a prompt like:
(base) C:\Users\yourname>


Activate the course environment and start IPython
Run:
conda activate pydata-book
ipython
You should then see:
In [1]:


Exit IPython
Run:
exit()


Optional: JupyterLab (modern web interface)

Activate the course environment:

conda activate pydata-book

Install JupyterLab (inside the environment):

conda install -c conda-forge jupyterlab

Start JupyterLab from your course-work folder:

cd C:\cmsc-1217\course-work
jupyter lab
A browser tab will open and the file browser will start in:
C:\cmsc-1217\course-work\
Important: keep the terminal window open while you use JupyterLab (it’s running the server).

title: Homework / Coursework policies
text:
Due dates and late work

All assignments must be submitted by the due date/time in D2L.
Late work is not accepted. (“Late” = not in the dropbox by the due/end date.)
Some assignments have multiple required components (video + file); missing any required component makes the assignment ineligible for grading.
Video work must be accessible at grading time or it is not accepted.
Students should archive/keep their submitted work.
Group work (if assigned) is not eligible for makeup.



Submission standards

Assignment-specific submission standards will be provided in instructions.
Work may be rejected or heavily penalized for not following standards, including:

incorrect file format
incorrect file naming
not following submission instructions

Students should contact the instructor before the due date with submission questions.
Assignments will not be accepted via email.



Tests / quizzes (D2L)

Quizzes/tests may be scheduled or unannounced; must be completed by the due date.
Password-protected test passwords may not be shared (integrity violation).
Multiple attempts may be allowed, with thresholds:

must score >60% on attempt 1 to unlock attempt 2
must score >80% on attempt 2 to unlock attempt 3 (if offered)

Time limits apply; exceeding the time limit may result in a 0 and block further work.
Students may not leave a quiz once started.
Auto-generated quizzes may prevent backtracking; students are responsible for careful navigation/submission.
No make-up tests/quizzes.



Grading practices (coursework-related)

Grades are posted in D2L; students are responsible for verifying accuracy.
Some activities may be assigned but not graded (self-review practice).
Rubrics are used for most activities; some items are auto-graded.
“Proof” files may be provided; students are expected to review feedback/proof files.
No extra credit / no additional assignments offered.
Some assignments may be pass/fail.



Video related coursework expectations

Some assignments require webcam-based video submission (and possibly desktop recording).
Student must be visable in any video assignment or the assignment will not be graded.
Student must introduce themselves by name, assignment, and course at the start of any video submission - “Hello my name is [name], this is the [assignment] for [class]”
Students must dress appropriately/considerately for online video assignments.

title: Week 1 Guide
text:
You are coming into this course with Python experience from Structured Programming Logic. That course focused on writing and running Python programs in a more traditional editor-and-console workflow.
In this course, you will still write Python, but the workspace will look different. We will use Jupyter notebooks as the main place to practice and show your work. A notebook combines explanation text, code, and output in one document, which makes it easier to follow examples, retry steps, and keep your work organized.
Week 1 is where you learn that workflow and get your course setup working. You will also be introduced to the tool ecosystem used throughout the textbook: pandas and NumPy for working with data, and matplotlib for basic plotting. Chapter 1 introduces this ecosystem and why it exists. Chapter 2 introduces notebooks and the interactive workflow.
This week is also a chance to get comfortable navigating the textbook and looking up unfamiliar terms. Do not be a passive learner. In an AI-driven environment, it is easy to copy an answer without understanding it, and it is also easy to get a confident answer that is wrong. Your job is to read, test, and confirm.
Section 1.6 in the textbook is especially useful this week. It explains how to navigate the book, how to read the code examples, and the import conventions used throughout (for example, numpy as np and pandas as pd). Treat 1.6 as your guide for how to read and use the book effectively.
One note before you start comparing your output to the book: the book often shows examples in an interactive In/Out style. Your notebook output may look similar but not identical, and that is fine. Focus on whether your code produces the correct result, not whether the formatting matches perfectly.

title: Week 1 Guide
text:
You are coming into this course with Python experience from Structured Programming Logic. That course focused on writing and running Python programs in a more traditional editor-and-console workflow.
In this course, you will still write Python, but the workspace will look different. We will use Jupyter notebooks as the main place to practice and show your work. A notebook combines explanation text, code, and output in one document, which makes it easier to follow examples, retry steps, and keep your work organized.
Week 1 is where you learn that workflow and get your course setup working. You will also be introduced to the tool ecosystem used throughout the textbook: pandas and NumPy for working with data, and matplotlib for basic plotting. Chapter 1 introduces this ecosystem and why it exists. Chapter 2 introduces notebooks and the interactive workflow.
This week is also a chance to get comfortable navigating the textbook and looking up unfamiliar terms. Do not be a passive learner. In an AI-driven environment, it is easy to copy an answer without understanding it, and it is also easy to get a confident answer that is wrong. Your job is to read, test, and confirm.
Section 1.6 in the textbook is especially useful this week. It explains how to navigate the book, how to read the code examples, and the import conventions used throughout (for example, numpy as np and pandas as pd). Treat 1.6 as your guide for how to read and use the book effectively.
One note before you start comparing your output to the book: the book often shows examples in an interactive In/Out style. Your notebook output may look similar but not identical, and that is fine. Focus on whether your code produces the correct result, not whether the formatting matches perfectly.

title: Week 1 Guide
text:
Course focus and expectations
This course is focused on the Python tools used to work with data. You will learn how to load data, inspect it, clean it, reshape it, summarize it, and visualize it. The emphasis is on building practical skill with the core libraries and the day-to-day workflow used in data work.
This course is not a statistics class. We are not spending the semester on statistical theory, inference, or formal methodology. When we use analytical ideas, it will be to support a tool we are learning and to help you interpret what your code produced. Think of this course as learning how to do the work in Python; your statistics elective covers more of the theory behind the methods.

title: Week 1 Guide
section: Core tools we will be using
text:
Core tools we will be using
The course uses a small set of tools repeatedly. You do not need to master them in Week 1. You do need to recognize the names and understand what each tool is used for.








Tool
What it is used for in this course
When you will notice it




NumPy
Working with numbers and arrays efficiently. It also supports many operations that pandas relies on.
When you see import numpy as np, or when we work with numeric operations and arrays.


pandas
Working with tables (DataFrames): loading data, cleaning it, reshaping it, combining it, and summarizing it.
Most weeks, because it is the main tool for manipulating data in this course.


matplotlib
Creating plots so you can see patterns and communicate results.
When we move into visualization, and whenever we need a chart to understand data.


Jupyter notebooks
A workspace that keeps explanations, code, and output together. This is how you will practice and show your work.
Every week, since most work will be done and submitted in notebooks.

title: Week 1 Guide
text:
Jupyter notebooks
In Structured Programming Logic, you typically wrote Python in a file and ran the whole program from start to finish. Each run started fresh.
A Jupyter notebook is different. A notebook is a single document that mixes:

text (explanations and notes)
code (Python)
output (tables, printed results, charts)

Instead of running one program from top to bottom every time, a notebook is built from cells. You run the notebook one cell at a time, in the order you choose.
This is powerful for learning and working with data because you can try something, see the result immediately, adjust it, and continue. The textbook discusses this interactive workflow and how notebooks fit into it.
The most important new idea is that the notebook runs in a live Python session. That session keeps everything you have already created (variables, imported libraries, data you loaded). If you run cells out of order, you can end up in a confusing state where your notebook depends on something you ran earlier but forgot to rerun.
Because of that, this course uses one consistent habit:
Restart Kernel and Run All
That is how you confirm your notebook works from a clean start and in the correct order.
Notebooks are a great learning tool, but they can also make it easy to skip real understanding. If you only change a few lines and press run, you can end up with working output without knowing why it works. Your goal in this class is not just to produce output, but to understand what your code is doing. When you use examples from the book, from a class notebook, or from AI, your job is to test small changes and confirm you still understand the result.
Using notebooks does not mean you are not writing code. You will still write Python in this course, but you will write it in smaller pieces and run it as you go. Many examples in the book are meant to be typed, run, and modified so you can see how changes affect the result. Chapter 2 discusses this interactive workflow and how to work effectively in notebooks.

title: Week 1 Guide
text:
Week 1 tasks
Complete the following this week:

Read Chapters 1 and 2 in the textbook in full. Work through the examples and exercises as you read.
Follow the guided setup videos to get your course environment setup.
Follow the Week 1 assignment instructions.
Complete the D2L quiz on Chapters 1 and 2.

title: Week 1 Guide
text:
Chapter overview for Week 1

Chapter 1: Preliminaries
Chapter 1 sets the direction for the book and the course. It explains what the book is focused on, the kinds of structured data you will work with, and the core Python libraries used throughout. It also explains the conventions used in the book (especially import conventions) and how to read the code examples.


Chapter 2: Python Language Basics, IPython, and Jupyter Notebooks
Chapter 2 introduces the interactive workflow used in the book. It explains what notebooks are, how running code interactively differs from running a script, and how tools like tab completion and built-in help make it easier to explore unfamiliar code and data as you work.

title: Week 1 Guide
text:
Knowledge goals for Week 1
By the end of Week 1, you should be able to explain:

What the book means by working with data in Python (the focus of the course)
The difference between NumPy and pandas at a high level
What a Jupyter notebook is, and how it differs from running a Python script
What a kernel is in the context of notebooks
What an environment is and why we use one for this course
What the book’s import conventions mean (for example, np and pd)
